global_computer.title: üåç Why Ethereum Works
global_computer.subtitle: A Transparent, Incorruptible Computing System
global_computer.hero_title: A computer that cannot lie, cannot be bribed, and cannot discriminate.
global_computer.hero_subtitle: Ethereum is a network of 500,000+ independent computers executing identical code. Every calculation is verified by thousands of machines. Every result is publicly auditable. The system produces the same output regardless of who you are, where you're from, or who you know.
global_computer.old_way_2: Outcomes can vary based on who processes your request
global_computer.old_way_3: Records can be modified by administrators
global_computer.old_way_5: Single points of failure and corruption
global_computer.eth_way_5: No single point of failure or corruption
global_computer.eth_way_6: Access requires only a valid transaction
global_computer.step1_desc: You send a payment instruction. This instruction is broadcast to the entire network ‚Äî visible to any observer immediately.
global_computer.step1_why_text: Your transaction is public from the moment you send it. No hidden queues, no discretionary delays.
global_computer.step2_desc2: across every continent. Each one has an identical copy.
global_computer.step2_why_text: No single entity controls transaction flow. The network continues operating even if thousands of nodes fail.
global_computer.step3_desc: Every 12 seconds, cryptographic algorithms select one validator to propose the next block. The selection is mathematically random and verifiable after the fact.
global_computer.step3_why_text: You cannot bribe the next block producer because their identity is unpredictable until selection occurs.
global_computer.step4_desc: The selected validator executes transactions according to predefined rules. The code runs identically regardless of the validator's preferences, nationality, or interests.
global_computer.step4_why_text: A smart contract approving a loan evaluates the same criteria for everyone. It cannot have a bad day, hold a grudge, or favor a friend.
global_computer.step5_desc: 31 additional validators independently verify the proposed block. If 2/3 confirm the execution is correct, the transaction is
global_computer.step5_why_text: Anyone can audit the full chain of execution. The math is public. The proofs are reproducible.
global_computer.analogy_text: Ethereum replaces institutional trust with mathematical verification. Instead of asking "Do I trust this bank?" you can ask "Can I verify this computation?" The answer is always yes ‚Äî every transaction, every contract execution, every state change is publicly auditable by anyone with an internet connection.
global_computer.benefit_global_desc: Operates identically in every jurisdiction. Geography is irrelevant to transaction validity.
global_computer.benefit_fast_desc: 12-second block times on Layer 1. Sub-second on Layer 2. Cryptographic finality, not probabilistic.
global_computer.benefit_secure_desc: Protected by mathematical proofs, not institutional promises. 500,000 independent validators.
global_computer.benefit_fair_desc: Same inputs always produce same outputs. No discretion, no exceptions, no special treatment.
global_computer.benefit_smart_desc: Self-executing contracts that enforce rules automatically. Escrow, loans, insurance ‚Äî without intermediary discretion.
global_computer.benefit_cheap_desc: Direct peer-to-peer settlement. Reduced reconciliation overhead. Minimal intermediary costs.
global_computer.performance_summary: Higher availability than traditional banking infrastructure. Cryptographic security guarantees rather than institutional ones.
global_computer.future_2025: Increased throughput, reduced costs, improved efficiency
global_computer.big_picture_text: This is infrastructure that operates on transparency rather than trust. Every claim is verifiable. Every execution is auditable. Every participant ‚Äî individual or institution ‚Äî interacts with the same immutable rules.
global_computer.big_picture_bold: The system's integrity comes from mathematics, not from the reputation of any institution.
global_computer.cta_text: Ethereum provides a coordination layer where rules are transparent, execution is verifiable, and outcomes are deterministic. No single entity can modify the rules, halt the system, or grant exceptions.
global_computer.cta_bold: This is infrastructure built on transparency, security, and mathematical verification.

architecture.title: üåê Complete Ethereum Architecture: L1, L2, MEV & Enterprise
architecture.consensus_manages_text: 500K+ validators, random proposer selection every 12 seconds
architecture.execution_manages_text: Transaction processing, state updates, smart contracts
architecture.execution_function_text: Mempool management, gas calculation, EVM execution
architecture.sequencer_function_text: Orders L2 transactions, provides instant confirmations
architecture.sequencer_evolution_text: Moving to Based rollups (L1 validators as sequencers)
architecture.enterprise_compliance_text: Known operators vs anonymous L1 validators
architecture.enterprise_support_text: SLAs available from corporate L2 operators
architecture.l2_timing3: Batch to L1 every few minutes via blobs
architecture.mev_note_text: ~90% of validators use MEV-Boost. Average MEV per block: 0.1-0.3 ETH ($200-600). Solo validators earn more when selected as proposer but only get selected every 2-3 months.
architecture.blob_step1_desc: 1000s of transactions on Arbitrum, Base, etc.
architecture.blob_step3_desc: Posted to L1 with blob reference hash
architecture.blob_cost_text: More blob space = cheaper L2 transactions
architecture.risk_mev_text: Mitigation: Direct sequencer relationships, private transaction pools, Based rollups (2025-2026)
architecture.risk_ordering_text: Solution: Smart contract design, nonce enforcement, atomic operations
architecture.risk_compliance_text: L2 advantage: Known operators (Coinbase, etc.) vs 500K anonymous validators
architecture.risk_exit_text: Mitigation: Multi-L2 strategy, market maker relationships
architecture.risk_reality_text: L2s reduce compliance burden (known entities) but require proper architecture for MEV protection and operational continuity.
architecture.roadmap_2025_text:
‚Ä¢ Gas limit: 30M ‚Üí 45M ‚Üí 150M
‚Ä¢ PeerDAS: Efficient blob sampling
‚Ä¢ ~18-25 TPS on L1
architecture.roadmap_2026_text:
‚Ä¢ Block time: 12s ‚Üí 6s
‚Ä¢ Verkle trees (stateless clients)
‚Ä¢ ~40-50 TPS on L1
architecture.roadmap_2027_text:
‚Ä¢ Single Slot Finality (12s)
‚Ä¢ Based rollups (decentralized sequencing)

architecture.roadmap_l2_text:

architecture.key_takeaway_text: Ethereum's architecture balances decentralization with performance. L1 provides security foundation (~15 TPS), L2s provide scale (~100K TPS), and the roadmap addresses enterprise concerns while maintaining decentralization principles.

why_works.title: ü§î Why Ethereum Works This Way
why_works.subtitle: Understanding the architecture through the problems it solves
why_works.analogy_banner_text: Think of Ethereum like a global justice system. Every transaction is a "case" that needs to be fairly processed, recorded, and made final. The architecture exists because you can't trust any single party to be the judge, jury, and record-keeper. Every component exists to solve a specific trust problem.
why_works.section_foundation: üèõÔ∏è The Foundation: Why Have Two Clients?
why_works.consensus_problem: How do 500,000+ validators around the world agree on who gets to add the next block, without anyone cheating or being able to predict who's next?
why_works.consensus_analogy: Like a judicial assignment committee that randomly selects which judge handles each case. No one can bribe their way to a specific case because the selection is unpredictable.
why_works.consensus_solution: The consensus client coordinates the random selection process and ensures everyone agrees on who was chosen. It's the "agreement layer" ‚Äî not about processing transactions, but about who gets to process them.
why_works.consensus_insight: üí° Separation of powers: The consensus client decides WHO, but not WHAT goes in the block.
why_works.execution_problem: Someone needs to actually run the code, update account balances, and make sure the math is right. How do we ensure every node gets the exact same result?
why_works.execution_analogy: Like the actual courtroom where cases are tried. The judge (consensus) said "hear this case," but the courtroom (execution) actually processes it according to the law (smart contracts).
why_works.execution_solution: The execution client is the "doing layer." It runs the EVM, processes transactions, and updates the global state. Separate from consensus so you can upgrade one without breaking the other.
why_works.execution_insight: üí° Modularity: If we find a better way to execute, we can swap execution clients without touching consensus.
why_works.section_mev: üí∞ The Ordering Problem: Why MEV Infrastructure?
why_works.flow_title: The Transaction Journey: Why Each Step Exists
why_works.builder_problem: Transaction order matters! If you're buying a token, someone could see your transaction, buy first, and sell to you at a higher price. This is "front-running."
why_works.builder_analogy: Like a court scheduler who groups related cases together efficiently. If Case A affects Case B, they need to be heard in the right order ‚Äî otherwise injustice happens.
why_works.builder_solution: Builders specialize in optimizing transaction order. By separating "who builds" from "who proposes," we create competition that actually benefits users through better MEV redistribution.
why_works.relay_problem: Builders and proposers don't trust each other. Builders don't want to reveal their blocks (someone could steal the strategy). Proposers don't want to blindly accept a block that might be invalid.
why_works.relay_analogy: Like an escrow service for sealed bids. The relay holds the builder's block without showing it, verifies it's valid, and only reveals it after the proposer commits. Trust without seeing.
why_works.relay_solution: Relays are trusted intermediaries that enable sealed-bid auctions. They verify blocks are valid without revealing contents, enabling fair competition between builders.
why_works.proposer_problem: Who gets the final say? You need someone with skin in the game (staked ETH) who will be punished if they cheat, but they shouldn't have unlimited power.
why_works.proposer_analogy: Like the presiding judge who signs off on the final verdict. They don't investigate the case themselves (that's the builder's job) ‚Äî they just verify and finalize it with their authority.
why_works.proposer_solution: The proposer provides the final cryptographic signature that makes the block official. They're randomly selected (can't be bribed in advance) and have 32 ETH at stake (can be punished for cheating).
why_works.l2_problem: Ethereum L1 processes ~15 transactions per second. That's 1.3 million per day. The world needs billions. We can't just make blocks bigger ‚Äî every node needs to verify everything.
why_works.l2_analogy: The Supreme Court (L1) can't hear every case ‚Äî it would collapse. So we have lower courts (L2s) that handle most cases, with the Supreme Court only reviewing summaries and handling appeals.
why_works.l2_solution: L2s do the heavy lifting (thousands of transactions) and only post compressed summaries to L1. L1 provides security guarantees; L2 provides speed and low cost.
why_works.l2_insight: üí° L1 security, L2 scale: The math proof or fraud proof ensures L2 can't cheat, even though L1 doesn't see every transaction.
why_works.sequencer_problem: On L2, someone needs to order transactions quickly (sub-second) before they're batched to L1. Waiting for L1's 12-second slots would kill the user experience.
why_works.sequencer_analogy: Like a court clerk who immediately logs your case filing and gives you a receipt. The official hearing (L1 finality) comes later, but you have instant confirmation your case was received.
why_works.sequencer_solution: The sequencer provides instant "soft confirmations" (your transaction is ordered) while batching happens in the background. Trade-off: current sequencers are centralized (known operators like Coinbase).
why_works.sequencer_insight: üí° Coming soon: "Based rollups" will use L1 validators as sequencers, removing the centralization trade-off.
why_works.data_problem: L2s post transaction data to L1. But storing data on L1 forever is expensive. We need the data available long enough to detect fraud, but not forever.
why_works.data_analogy: Like court records that must be kept for 18 days (the appeal period). After that, the verdict is final and you only need to keep the summary. Full transcripts can be archived elsewhere.
why_works.data_solution: Blobs are temporary data storage (~18 days) that's much cheaper than permanent storage. L2s post their data there, anyone can verify fraud during the window, then it's pruned.
why_works.data_insight: üí° Temporary availability is enough: If no one proves fraud in 18 days, we assume it's valid. This makes L2 transactions 10-100x cheaper.
why_works.prover_problem: L1 can't re-execute all L2 transactions (that defeats the purpose). But how do we know the L2 didn't lie about what happened?
why_works.prover_analogy_optimistic_text: Lower court verdicts are assumed valid unless someone appeals within 7 days.
why_works.prover_analogy_zk_text: Every verdict comes with a mathematical proof that the judge followed the law correctly. No appeals needed.
why_works.prover_solution: Provers create cryptographic evidence that L2 state transitions are valid. Optimistic = cheaper but slower withdrawals. ZK = more expensive but instant finality.
why_works.principle_separation_text: Every component does one thing well. Consensus picks WHO. Execution does WHAT. Builders optimize ORDER. This modularity enables upgrades without breaking everything.
why_works.principle_unpredictability_text: Random proposer selection prevents corruption. You can't bribe the next block producer because no one knows who it will be until the last moment.
why_works.principle_incentives_text: Validators stake 32 ETH ‚Äî skin in the game. Cheating means losing your stake. Honest behavior is more profitable than attacking.
why_works.principle_verify_text: Every claim can be verified independently. Fraud proofs, validity proofs, attestations ‚Äî the system assumes everyone might lie and builds verification into every step.

finance.title: Global Finance Infrastructure
finance.subtitle: Actors, pipes, and how money moves
finance.context_p1: We often hear that Ethereum will become the infrastructure of the global economy. But to build that future, we need to understand how the current system actually works.
finance.context_p2: Too often, Web3 conversations skip over the real mechanics of global finance ‚Äî the pipes that move $7 trillion in FX daily, settle $3.79 quadrillion in securities annually, and protect against counterparty failures that have taken down major banks.
finance.context_p3: This document is the EEA's contribution to closing that gap. If we want Ethereum to provide meaningful upgrades to financial infrastructure, we need to understand what we're improving ‚Äî and why these systems were built in the first place.
finance.context_footer: The opportunity is real. So is the complexity.
finance.buy_side_why: Owns capital and seeks returns. Makes allocation decisions. Pays for access to markets, liquidity, and execution.
finance.sell_side_subtitle: How do we package and distribute risk?
finance.sell_side_why: Manufactures liquidity and distributes products. Earns fees for providing market access, execution, and balance sheet.
finance.rtgs_problem: When banks transfer money to each other, who guarantees the payment is real? A bank could promise $1B, receive goods, then fail before actually paying.
finance.rtgs_example_text: When this major US bank failed, other banks had billions in unsettled interbank payments at risk. The Fed had to intervene with $4.5B to prevent a chain reaction.
finance.rtgs_solution: Payments settle in central bank money ‚Äî the only money with zero counterparty risk. Each transfer is final and irrevocable within seconds. Banks can only send what they have in their central bank account.
finance.card_problem: A merchant in Paris wants to accept payment from a tourist's US bank. They've never met, don't trust each other, and need instant authorization. Who guarantees the merchant gets paid? Who protects the consumer from fraud?
finance.card_example_text: Every merchant would need bilateral agreements with every bank worldwide. Fraud liability would be unclear. Authorization would take days, not seconds.
finance.card_solution: Networks provide universal acceptance (one integration = millions of merchants), instant authorization, fraud protection with chargeback rights, and guaranteed merchant payment. They net millions of transactions and settle once daily.
finance.exchange_problem: You want to sell 10,000 shares of Apple. Someone in Tokyo wants to buy. How do you find each other? How do you know you're getting a fair price and not being front-run?
finance.exchange_example_text: Stock trading happened in coffee houses. Prices varied wildly between dealers. Insider trading was rampant. The Buttonwood Agreement created the NYSE to establish fair, transparent pricing.
finance.exchange_solution: Central order books show all bids/offers. Price-time priority ensures fairness. Surveillance detects manipulation. Everyone sees the same price at the same time. Liquidity concentrates, reducing spreads.
finance.ccp_problem: You agree to buy $100M in bonds from Bank X, settling in 2 days. Overnight, Bank X fails. You've already hedged your position. Now you're exposed AND need to find a new seller ‚Äî possibly at a worse price.
finance.ccp_example_text: $35T in derivatives, $600B+ in outstanding trades frozen overnight. Counterparties globally didn't know if trades would settle. CCP-cleared trades settled cleanly; bilateral trades took years to unwind in court.
finance.ccp_solution: CCP becomes buyer to every seller, seller to every buyer. Collects margin daily (if you drop 5%, you post cash that day). Nets 1000 trades into 1 position. Maintains default fund from all members. If a member fails, CCP auctions their portfolio.
finance.csd_problem: After clearing, the asset must actually move. But what if you send $100M and never receive the shares? Or send shares and never get paid? With millions of trades daily, how do you track who owns what?
finance.csd_example_text: Trading volume overwhelmed back offices. Physical stock certificates were lost, stolen, or misdelivered. NYSE had to close on Wednesdays for months. $400M in securities simply "disappeared."
finance.csd_solution: Securities exist as electronic book entries, not paper. DvP (Delivery versus Payment) ensures atomic swap ‚Äî you only get shares if payment clears, and vice versa. Single source of truth for ownership. Corporate actions processed automatically.
finance.fx_full: Continuous Linked Settlement / Payment vs Payment
finance.fx_problem: In FX, you're exchanging two currencies. You send ‚Ç¨100M to a German bank at 9am Frankfurt time. They should send you $110M ‚Äî but their US correspondent bank operates in New York, 6 hours behind. If they fail before NY opens, you've lost ‚Ç¨100M.
finance.fx_example_text: German regulators closed Herstatt at 3:30pm Frankfurt (10:30am NY). Counterparties had already paid Deutschmarks but never received dollars. $620M frozen. This "Herstatt Risk" shaped FX infrastructure for 50 years.
finance.fx_solution: PvP = both legs settle simultaneously or neither does. CLS holds both payments in escrow and releases only when both parties have funded. Eliminates principal risk entirely. Operates in a 5-hour window when all major markets overlap.
